thread.title: BoQ hopes to benefit from Qld house prices
thread.title_full: BoQ hopes to benefit from Qld house prices

title: BoQ hopes to benefit from Qld house prices
text:
View Photo 

Bank of Queensland hopes to benefit from the house price boom outside its home state after it announced a record full year profit of $318 million. 
The bank announced a 22 per cent increase in net profit for the 12 months to August 31 and, although Queensland accounted for less than half its total lending for the first time, chief executive Jon Sutton said the organisation could benefit as people head north in search of more bang for their housing buck. 
"In time, better housing affordability should encourage net migration to Queensland, further boosting the state economy," Mr Sutton said. 
The average price of a home in Sydney in the 12 months to March was $786,000, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, while in Melbourne it was $527,500. 
In Brisbane, the price was a more modest $480,000. 
The bank will start offering Virgin Money branded mortgages in February and plans to expand the number of brokers offering its products from 2,500 to 4,000 at the end of the 2015/16 financial year. 
BoQ acquired Virgin Money's Australian business for $40 million in 2013. 
The use of brokers helped the bank increase total lending 7.0 per cent on the prior corresponding period and changed the composition of lends so that more than 50 per cent of total lending is outside Queensland. 
There was a $10 million increase in loan impairment costs at the bank's BOQ Finance unit, with the hit mostly coming in the second half from defaults and write-offs related to mining. But, overall loan impairment expenses were down 14 per cent to $74 million. 
BoQ's cash earnings after tax for the 12 months to August 31, most banks' preferred measure of performance, increased 19 per cent to $357 million. 
The bank attributed the improvement to a 15 basis point rise in net interest margins - the profit it makes on loans - to 1.97 per cent, mostly due to the higher margin BOQ Specialist service it acquired from Investec in 2014. 
The professional finance unit generated cash earnings of $43 million, beating guidance of $38 million by almost 13 per cent. 
"BoQ has now delivered record results for five successive halves, a significant achievement in an environment of low growth and changing regulations," Mr Sutton said. 
"Though we have more work to do ... we remain a bank that has come a long way in recent years and we are confident that we are well positioned for sustainable growth into the future." 
Mr Sutton forecast further "solid returns" for shareholders. 
Bank of Queensland shares were up 90.5 cents at $12.515. 
BULLISH BANK OF QUEENSLAND 
* Net profit up 22pct to $318m 
* Revenue up 16pct to $1.088b 
* Fully-franked final dividend up four cents to 38 cents @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook BoQ hopes to benefit from Qld house prices AAP
